\doxysubsection{Detailed Description}
\subsubsection*{template$<$typename T$>$\newline
struct cimg\+\_\+library\+\_\+suffixed\+::\+C\+Img$<$ T $>$}

Class representing an image (up to 4 dimensions wide), each pixel being of type {\ttfamily T}. 

This is the main class of the C\+Img Library. It declares and constructs an image, allows access to its pixel values, and is able to perform various image operations.

\begin{DoxyParagraph}{Image representation}

\end{DoxyParagraph}
A C\+Img image is defined as an instance of the container {\ttfamily C\+Img$<$\+T$>$}, which contains a regular grid of pixels, each pixel value being of type {\ttfamily T}. The image grid can have up to 4 dimensions\+: width, height, depth and number of channels. Usually, the three first dimensions are used to describe spatial coordinates {\ttfamily (x,y,z)}, while the number of channels is rather used as a vector-\/valued dimension (it may describe the R,G,B color channels for instance). If you need a fifth dimension, you can use image lists {\ttfamily C\+Img\+List$<$\+T$>$} rather than simple images {\ttfamily C\+Img$<$\+T$>$}.

Thus, the {\ttfamily C\+Img$<$\+T$>$} class is able to represent volumetric images of vector-\/valued pixels, as well as images with less dimensions (1D scalar signal, 2D color images, ...). Most member functions of the class \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg}{C\+Img}}$<${\ttfamily T$>$} are designed to handle this maximum case of (3+1) dimensions.

Concerning the pixel value type {\ttfamily T\+:} fully supported template types are the basic C++ types\+: {\ttfamily unsigned char, char, short, unsigned int, int, unsigned long, long, float, double, ... }. Typically, fast image display can be done using {\ttfamily C\+Img$<$unsigned char$>$} images, while complex image processing algorithms may be rather coded using {\ttfamily C\+Img$<$float$>$} or {\ttfamily C\+Img$<$double$>$} images that have floating-\/point pixel values. The default value for the template T is {\ttfamily float}. Using your own template types may be possible. However, you will certainly have to define the complete set of arithmetic and logical operators for your class.

\begin{DoxyParagraph}{Image structure}

\end{DoxyParagraph}
The {\ttfamily C\+Img$<$\+T$>$} structure contains {\itshape six} fields\+:
\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item {\ttfamily \+\_\+width} defines the number of {\itshape columns} of the image (size along the X-\/axis).
\item {\ttfamily \+\_\+height} defines the number of {\itshape rows} of the image (size along the Y-\/axis).
\item {\ttfamily \+\_\+depth} defines the number of {\itshape slices} of the image (size along the Z-\/axis).
\item {\ttfamily \+\_\+spectrum} defines the number of {\itshape channels} of the image (size along the C-\/axis).
\item {\ttfamily \+\_\+data} defines a {\itshape pointer} to the {\itshape pixel} {\itshape data} (of type {\ttfamily T}).
\item {\ttfamily \+\_\+is\+\_\+shared} is a boolean that tells if the memory buffer {\ttfamily data} is shared with another image.
\end{DoxyItemize}

You can access these fields publicly although it is recommended to use the dedicated functions \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a2d7b769d447c0451a2f43c77e997beff}{width()}}, \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a49834fd555c4a8362100bc628f1b03bb}{height()}}, \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_aa708d2050f866a341896aca528615d2d}{depth()}}, \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a03cdb8e4b45371862c65c3b5be7b697e}{spectrum()}} and ptr() to do so. Image dimensions are not limited to a specific range (as long as you got enough available memory). A value of {\itshape 1} usually means that the corresponding dimension is {\itshape flat}. If one of the dimensions is {\itshape 0}, or if the data pointer is null, the image is considered as {\itshape empty}. Empty images should not contain any pixel data and thus, will not be processed by \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg}{C\+Img}} member functions (a \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImgInstanceException}{C\+Img\+Instance\+Exception}} will be thrown instead). Pixel data are stored in memory, in a non interlaced mode (See cimg\+\_\+storage).

\begin{DoxyParagraph}{Image declaration and construction}

\end{DoxyParagraph}
Declaring an image can be done by using one of the several available constructors. Here is a list of the most used\+:


\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item Construct images from arbitrary dimensions\+:
\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item {\ttfamily C\+Img$<$char$>$ img;} declares an empty image.
\item {\ttfamily C\+Img$<$unsigned char$>$ img(128,128);} declares a 128x128 greyscale image with {\ttfamily unsigned} {\ttfamily char} pixel values.
\item {\ttfamily C\+Img$<$double$>$ img(3,3);} declares a 3x3 matrix with {\ttfamily double} coefficients.
\item {\ttfamily C\+Img$<$unsigned char$>$ img(256,256,1,3);} declares a 256x256x1x3 (color) image (colors are stored as an image with three channels).
\item {\ttfamily C\+Img$<$double$>$ img(128,128,128);} declares a 128x128x128 volumetric and greyscale image (with {\ttfamily double} pixel values).
\item {\ttfamily C\+Img$<$$>$ img(128,128,128,3);} declares a 128x128x128 volumetric color image (with {\ttfamily float} pixels, which is the default value of the template parameter {\ttfamily T}).
\item {\bfseries{Note\+:}} images pixels are {\bfseries{not automatically initialized to 0}}. You may use the function {\ttfamily \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_ab7ab19191c8b913121d5c99a0e5806db}{fill()}}} to do it, or use the specific constructor taking 5 parameters like this\+: {\ttfamily C\+Img$<$$>$ img(128,128,128,3,0);} declares a 128x128x128 volumetric color image with all pixel values to 0.
\end{DoxyItemize}
\item Construct images from filenames\+:
\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item {\ttfamily C\+Img$<$unsigned char$>$ img(\char`\"{}image.\+jpg\char`\"{});} reads a J\+P\+EG color image from the file \char`\"{}image.\+jpg\char`\"{}.
\item {\ttfamily C\+Img$<$float$>$ img(\char`\"{}analyze.\+hdr\char`\"{});} reads a volumetric image (A\+N\+A\+L\+Y\+Z\+E7.\+5 format) from the file \char`\"{}analyze.\+hdr\char`\"{}.
\item {\bfseries{Note\+:}} You need to install \href{http://www.imagemagick.org}{\texttt{ Image\+Magick}} to be able to read common compressed image formats (J\+PG,P\+NG, ...) (See cimg\+\_\+files\+\_\+io).
\end{DoxyItemize}
\item Construct images from C-\/style arrays\+:
\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item {\ttfamily C\+Img$<$int$>$ img(data\+\_\+buffer,256,256);} constructs a 256x256 greyscale image from a {\ttfamily int$\ast$} buffer {\ttfamily data\+\_\+buffer} (of size 256x256=65536).
\item {\ttfamily C\+Img$<$unsigned char$>$ img(data\+\_\+buffer,256,256,1,3);} constructs a 256x256 color image from a {\ttfamily unsigned} {\ttfamily char$\ast$} buffer {\ttfamily data\+\_\+buffer} (where R,G,B channels follow each others).
\end{DoxyItemize}

The complete list of constructors can be found \href{\#constructors}{\texttt{ here}}.
\end{DoxyItemize}

\begin{DoxyParagraph}{Most useful functions}

\end{DoxyParagraph}
The {\ttfamily C\+Img$<$\+T$>$} class contains a lot of functions that operates on images. Some of the most useful are\+:


\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_afdb84f77b8c310ea9bf9c430f66cc70b}{operator()()}}\+: Read or write pixel values.
\item \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a33594316b522954b5388986c9b15a52a}{display()}}\+: displays the image in a new window. 
\end{DoxyItemize}

Simple iterator type, to loop through each pixel value of an image instance. 

\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item The {\ttfamily \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a14869a2d3849994eb07f80d2e2c36bbd}{C\+Img$<$\+T$>$\+::iterator}}} type is defined to be a {\ttfamily T$\ast$}.
\item You will seldom have to use iterators in C\+Img, most classical operations being achieved (often in a faster way) using methods of {\ttfamily C\+Img$<$\+T$>$}. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}
\begin{DoxyParagraph}{Example}

\begin{DoxyCode}{0}

\DoxyCodeLine{\textcolor{keywordflow}{for} (\mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a14869a2d3849994eb07f80d2e2c36bbd}{CImg<float>::iterator}} it = \mbox{\hyperlink{namespacecimg__library__suffixed_a4b2be1eebcd69c87bde0b5757cad1938}{img}}.begin(), it<\mbox{\hyperlink{namespacecimg__library__suffixed_a4b2be1eebcd69c87bde0b5757cad1938}{img}}.end(); ++it) *it = 0;}

Destroy image. 

\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item The pixel buffer \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a5a062592b78f33dd2813cc59985e61a2}{data()}} is deallocated if necessary, e.\+g. for non-\/empty and non-\/shared image instances.
\item Destroying an empty or shared image does nothing actually. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}
\begin{DoxyWarning}{Warning}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item When destroying a non-\/shared image, make sure that you will {\itshape not} operate on a remaining shared image that shares its buffer with the destroyed instance, in order to avoid further invalid memory access (to a deallocated buffer). 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyWarning}

Construct empty image. 

\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item An empty image has no pixel data and all of its dimensions \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a2d7b769d447c0451a2f43c77e997beff}{width()}}, \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a49834fd555c4a8362100bc628f1b03bb}{height()}}, \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_aa708d2050f866a341896aca528615d2d}{depth()}}, \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a03cdb8e4b45371862c65c3b5be7b697e}{spectrum()}} are set to {\ttfamily 0}, as well as its pixel buffer pointer \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a5a062592b78f33dd2813cc59985e61a2}{data()}}.
\item An empty image may be re-\/assigned afterwards, e.\+g. with the family of \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a95898e33c8270ae81d3addd9302d18bc}{assign(unsigned int,unsigned int,unsigned int,unsigned int)}} methods, or by \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a8e9ce81272aa269f51f670ba52b0ca70}{operator=(const C\+Img$<$t$>$\&)}}. In all cases, the type of pixels stays {\ttfamily T}.
\item An empty image is never shared. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}
\begin{DoxyParagraph}{Example}

\begin{DoxyCode}{0}
\DoxyCodeLine{CImg<float> img1, img2;      \textcolor{comment}{// Construct two empty images}}

\DoxyCodeLine{img2 = img1.get\_rand(0,255); \textcolor{comment}{// Re-\/assign 'img2' to be a random-\/valued version of 'img1'}}
\DoxyCodeLine{img2.assign();               \textcolor{comment}{// Re-\/assign 'img2' to be an empty image again}}
\end{DoxyCode}
 
\end{DoxyParagraph}

\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}

\item Setting one dimension {\ttfamily size\+\_\+x},{\ttfamily size\+\_\+y},{\ttfamily size\+\_\+z} or {\ttfamily size\+\_\+c} to {\ttfamily 0} leads to the construction of an {\itshape empty} image.
\item A {\ttfamily \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImgInstanceException}{C\+Img\+Instance\+Exception}}} is thrown when the pixel buffer cannot be allocated (e.\+g. when requested size is too big for available memory).

\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item If {\ttfamily is\+\_\+shared} is {\ttfamily false}, the image instance allocates its own pixel buffer, and values from the specified input buffer are copied to the instance buffer. If buffer types {\ttfamily T} and {\ttfamily t} are different, a regular static cast is performed during buffer copy.
\item Otherwise, the image instance does {\itshape not} allocate a new buffer, and uses the input memory buffer as its own pixel buffer. This case requires that types {\ttfamily T} and {\ttfamily t} are the same. Later, destroying such a shared image will not deallocate the pixel buffer, this task being obviously charged to the initial buffer allocator.

Construct image copy. 

Construct a new image instance with pixels of type {\ttfamily T}, as a copy of an existing {\ttfamily C\+Img$<$t$>$} instance. 
\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em img} & Input image to copy. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item Constructed copy has the same size \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a2d7b769d447c0451a2f43c77e997beff}{width()}} x \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a49834fd555c4a8362100bc628f1b03bb}{height()}} x \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_aa708d2050f866a341896aca528615d2d}{depth()}} x \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a03cdb8e4b45371862c65c3b5be7b697e}{spectrum()}} and pixel values as the input image {\ttfamily img}.
\item If input image {\ttfamily img} is {\itshape shared} and if types {\ttfamily T} and {\ttfamily t} are the same, the constructed copy is also {\itshape shared}, and shares its pixel buffer with {\ttfamily img}. Modifying a pixel value in the constructed copy will thus also modifies it in the input image {\ttfamily img}. This behavior is needful to allow functions to return shared images.
\item Otherwise, the constructed copy allocates its own pixel buffer, and copies pixel values from the input image {\ttfamily img} into its buffer. The copied pixel values may be eventually statically casted if types {\ttfamily T} and {\ttfamily t} are different.
\item Constructing a copy from an image {\ttfamily img} when types {\ttfamily t} and {\ttfamily T} are the same is significantly faster than with different types.
\item A {\ttfamily \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImgInstanceException}{C\+Img\+Instance\+Exception}}} is thrown when the pixel buffer cannot be allocated (e.\+g. not enough available memory). 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}

Construct a new image instance with pixels of type {\ttfamily T}, as a copy of an existing {\ttfamily C\+Img$<$t$>$} instance, while forcing the shared state of the constructed copy. 
\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em img} & Input image to copy. \\
\hline
{\em is\+\_\+shared} & Tells about the shared state of the constructed copy. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item Similar to \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_ac6e7967414ff3ce06e9a053a1096e702}{C\+Img(const C\+Img$<$t$>$\&)}}, except that it allows to decide the shared state of the constructed image, which does not depend anymore on the shared state of the input image {\ttfamily img\+:}

Access to a pixel value at a specified offset, using Neumann boundary conditions. 

Return a reference to the pixel value of the image instance located at a specified {\ttfamily offset}, or to the nearest pixel location in the image instance in case of out-\/of-\/bounds access. 
\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em offset} & Offset to the desired pixel value. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item Similar to at(int,const T), except that an out-\/of-\/bounds access returns the value of the nearest pixel in the image instance, regarding the specified offset, i.\+e.
\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item If {\ttfamily offset$<$0}, then {\ttfamily img}\mbox{[}0\mbox{]} is returned.
\item If {\ttfamily offset$>$=img.\+size()}, then {\ttfamily img}\mbox{[}img.\+size() -\/ 1\mbox{]} is returned.
\end{DoxyItemize}
\item Due to the additional boundary checking operation, this method is slower than \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_afdb84f77b8c310ea9bf9c430f66cc70b}{operator()()}}. Use it when you are {\itshape not} sure about the validity of the specified pixel offset.
\item If you know your image instance is {\itshape not} empty, you may rather use the slightly faster method {\ttfamily \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a66df8793badcb16fc00b20b90929f5df}{\+\_\+at(int)}}}. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}

Compute the arctangent2 of each pixel value. 

Replace each pixel value $I_{(x,y,z,c)}$ of the image instance by its arctangent2 $\mathrm{atan2}(I_{(x,y,z,c)})$. 
\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}

\hline
\end{DoxyParams}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item The \textbackslash{}inplace of this method statically casts the computed values to the pixel type {\ttfamily T}.
\item The \textbackslash{}newinstance returns a {\ttfamily C\+Img$<$float$>$} image, if the pixel type {\ttfamily T} is {\itshape not} float-\/valued. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}

Access to a pixel value, using Dirichlet boundary conditions for the X-\/coordinate. 

Return a reference to the pixel value of the image instance located at ({\ttfamily x},{\ttfamily y},{\ttfamily z},{\ttfamily c}), or to a specified default value in case of out-\/of-\/bounds access along the X-\/axis. 
\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em x} & X-\/coordinate of the pixel value. \\
\hline
{\em y} & Y-\/coordinate of the pixel value. \\
\hline
{\em z} & Z-\/coordinate of the pixel value. \\
\hline
{\em c} & C-\/coordinate of the pixel value. \\
\hline
{\em out\+\_\+value} & Default value returned if {\ttfamily }({\ttfamily x},{\ttfamily y},{\ttfamily z},{\ttfamily c}) is outside image bounds. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item Similar to \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_afdb84f77b8c310ea9bf9c430f66cc70b}{operator()()}}, except that an out-\/of-\/bounds access along the X-\/axis returns the specified value {\ttfamily out\+\_\+value}.
\item Due to the additional boundary checking operation, this method is slower than \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_afdb84f77b8c310ea9bf9c430f66cc70b}{operator()()}}. Use it when you are {\itshape not} sure about the validity of the specified pixel coordinates. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}
\begin{DoxyWarning}{Warning}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item There is {\itshape no} boundary checking performed for the Y,Z and C-\/coordinates, so they must be inside image bounds. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyWarning}

Access to a pixel value, using Neumann boundary conditions for the X-\/coordinate. 

Return a reference to the pixel value of the image instance located at ({\ttfamily x},{\ttfamily y},{\ttfamily z},{\ttfamily c}), or to the nearest pixel location in the image instance in case of out-\/of-\/bounds access along the X-\/axis. 
\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em x} & X-\/coordinate of the pixel value. \\
\hline
{\em y} & Y-\/coordinate of the pixel value. \\
\hline
{\em z} & Z-\/coordinate of the pixel value. \\
\hline
{\em c} & C-\/coordinate of the pixel value. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item Similar to at(int,int,int,int,const T), except that an out-\/of-\/bounds access returns the value of the nearest pixel in the image instance, regarding the specified X-\/coordinate.
\item Due to the additional boundary checking operation, this method is slower than \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_afdb84f77b8c310ea9bf9c430f66cc70b}{operator()()}}. Use it when you are {\itshape not} sure about the validity of the specified pixel coordinates.
\item If you know your image instance is {\itshape not} empty, you may rather use the slightly faster method {\ttfamily \+\_\+at(int,int,int,int)}. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}
\begin{DoxyWarning}{Warning}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item There is {\itshape no} boundary checking performed for the Y,Z and C-\/coordinates, so they must be inside image bounds. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyWarning}

\hline
{\em c} & C-\/coordinate of the pixel value. \\

Return the number of image slices. 

Return the image depth, i.\+e. the image dimension along the Z-\/axis. \begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item The \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_aa708d2050f866a341896aca528615d2d}{depth()}} of an empty image is equal to {\ttfamily 0}.
\item \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_aa708d2050f866a341896aca528615d2d}{depth()}} is typically equal to {\ttfamily 1} when considering usual 2D images. When \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_aa708d2050f866a341896aca528615d2d}{depth()}}{\ttfamily $>$} {\ttfamily 1}, the image is said to be {\itshape volumetric}.
\item \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_aa708d2050f866a341896aca528615d2d}{depth()}} returns an {\ttfamily int}, although the image depth is internally stored as an {\ttfamily unsigned} {\ttfamily int}. Using an {\ttfamily int} is safer and prevents arithmetic traps possibly encountered when doing calculations involving {\ttfamily unsigned} {\ttfamily int} variables. Access to the initial {\ttfamily unsigned} {\ttfamily int} variable is possible (though not recommended) by {\ttfamily ($\ast$this).\+\_\+depth}. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}

\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item The curve is a 2D cubic Bezier spline, from the set of specified starting/ending points and corresponding velocity vectors.
\item The spline is drawn as a sequence of connected segments. The {\ttfamily precision} parameter sets the average number of pixels in each drawn segment.
\item A cubic Bezier curve is sometimes defined by a set of 4 points \{ ({\ttfamily x0},{\ttfamily y0}), ({\ttfamily xa},{\ttfamily ya}), ({\ttfamily xb},{\ttfamily yb}), ({\ttfamily x1},{\ttfamily y1}) \} where ({\ttfamily x0},{\ttfamily y0}) is the starting point, ({\ttfamily x1},{\ttfamily y1}) is the ending point and ({\ttfamily xa},{\ttfamily ya}), ({\ttfamily xb},{\ttfamily yb}) are two {\itshape control} points. The starting and ending velocities ({\ttfamily u0},{\ttfamily v0}) and ({\ttfamily u1},{\ttfamily v1}) can be deduced easily from the control points as {\ttfamily u0} = ({\ttfamily xa} -\/ {\ttfamily x0}), {\ttfamily v0} = ({\ttfamily ya} -\/ {\ttfamily y0}), {\ttfamily u1} = ({\ttfamily x1} -\/ {\ttfamily xb}) and {\ttfamily v1} = ({\ttfamily y1} -\/ {\ttfamily yb}). 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}

Test if pixel buffers of instance and input images overlap. 

Return {\ttfamily true}, if pixel buffers attached to image instance and input image {\ttfamily img} overlap, and {\ttfamily false} otherwise. 
\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em img} & Input image to compare with. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item Buffer overlapping may happen when manipulating {\itshape shared} images.
\item If two image buffers overlap, operating on one of the image will probably modify the other one.
\item Most of the time, {\ttfamily C\+Img$<$\+T$>$} instances are {\itshape non-\/shared} and do not overlap between each others. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}
\begin{DoxyParagraph}{Example}

\begin{DoxyCode}{0}
\DoxyCodeLine{\textcolor{keyword}{const} CImg<float>}
\DoxyCodeLine{  img1(\textcolor{stringliteral}{"reference.jpg"}),             \textcolor{comment}{// Load RGB-\/color image}}
\DoxyCodeLine{  img2 = img1.get\_shared\_channel(1); \textcolor{comment}{// Get shared version of the green channel}}
\DoxyCodeLine{\textcolor{keywordflow}{if} (img1.is\_overlapped(img2)) \{      \textcolor{comment}{// Test succeeds, 'img1' and 'img2' overlaps}}
\DoxyCodeLine{  std::printf(\textcolor{stringliteral}{"Buffers overlap!\(\backslash\)n"});}
\DoxyCodeLine{\}}
\end{DoxyCode}
 
\end{DoxyParagraph}

Test shared state of the pixel buffer. 

Return {\ttfamily true} if image instance has a shared memory buffer, and {\ttfamily false} otherwise. \begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item A shared image do not own his pixel buffer \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a5a062592b78f33dd2813cc59985e61a2}{data()}} and will not deallocate it on destruction.
\item Most of the time, a {\ttfamily C\+Img$<$\+T$>$} image instance will {\itshape not} be shared.
\item A shared image can only be obtained by a limited set of constructors and methods (see list below). 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}

Return pixel value, using linear interpolation and Dirichlet boundary conditions for the X-\/coordinate. 

Return a linearly-\/interpolated pixel value of the image instance located at ({\ttfamily fx},{\ttfamily y},{\ttfamily z},{\ttfamily c}), or a specified default value in case of out-\/of-\/bounds access along the X-\/axis. 
\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em fx} & X-\/coordinate of the pixel value (float-\/valued). \\
\hline
{\em y} & Y-\/coordinate of the pixel value. \\
\hline
{\em z} & Z-\/coordinate of the pixel value. \\
\hline
{\em c} & C-\/coordinate of the pixel value. \\
\hline
{\em out\+\_\+value} & Default value returned if {\ttfamily }({\ttfamily fx},{\ttfamily y},{\ttfamily z},{\ttfamily c}) is outside image bounds. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item Similar to at\+X(int,int,int,int,const T), except that the returned pixel value is approximated by a linear interpolation along the X-\/axis, if corresponding coordinates are not integers.
\item The type of the returned pixel value is extended to {\ttfamily float}, if the pixel type {\ttfamily T} is not float-\/valued. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}
\begin{DoxyWarning}{Warning}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item There is {\itshape no} boundary checking performed for the Y,Z and C-\/coordinates, so they must be inside image bounds. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyWarning}

Transfer content of an image instance into another one. 

Transfer the dimensions and the pixel buffer content of an image instance into another one, and replace instance by an empty image. It avoids the copy of the pixel buffer when possible. 
\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em img} & Destination image. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item Pixel types {\ttfamily T} and {\ttfamily t} of source and destination images can be different, though the process is designed to be instantaneous when {\ttfamily T} and {\ttfamily t} are the same. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}
\begin{DoxyParagraph}{Example}

\begin{DoxyCode}{0}
\DoxyCodeLine{CImg<float> src(256,256,1,3,0), \textcolor{comment}{// Construct a 256x256x1x3 (color) image filled with value '0'}}
\DoxyCodeLine{            dest(16,16);        \textcolor{comment}{// Construct a 16x16x1x1 (scalar) image}}
\DoxyCodeLine{src.move\_to(dest);              \textcolor{comment}{// Now, 'src' is empty and 'dest' is the 256x256x1x3 image}}
\end{DoxyCode}
 
\end{DoxyParagraph}

Transfer content of an image instance into a new image in an image list. 

Transfer the dimensions and the pixel buffer content of an image instance into a newly inserted image at position {\ttfamily pos} in specified {\ttfamily C\+Img\+List$<$t$>$} instance. 
\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em list} & Destination list. \\
\hline
{\em pos} & Position of the newly inserted image in the list. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item When optional parameter {\ttfamily pos} is omitted, the image instance is transferred as a new image at the end of the specified {\ttfamily list}.

\end{DoxyNote}

Implicitly cast an image into a {\ttfamily T$\ast$}. 

Implicitly cast a {\ttfamily C\+Img$<$\+T$>$} instance into a {\ttfamily T$\ast$} or {\ttfamily const} {\ttfamily T$\ast$} pointer, whether the image instance is {\itshape const} or not. The returned pointer points on the first value of the image pixel buffer. \begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\item This implicit conversion is convenient to test the empty state of images (\mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a5a062592b78f33dd2813cc59985e61a2}{data()}} being {\ttfamily 0} in this case), e.\+g.

\DoxyCodeLine{  \textcolor{keywordflow}{if} (!img2) \{                   \textcolor{comment}{// Test succeeds, 'img2' is an empty image}}
\DoxyCodeLine{    std::printf(\textcolor{stringliteral}{"'img1' is not empty, 'img2' is empty."});}
\DoxyCodeLine{  \}}
\DoxyCodeLine{\}}
\end{DoxyCode}

\item Range of pixel coordinates start from {\ttfamily (0,0,0,0)} to {\ttfamily (\mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a2d7b769d447c0451a2f43c77e997beff}{width()}} -\/ 1,\mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a49834fd555c4a8362100bc628f1b03bb}{height()}} -\/ 1,\mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_aa708d2050f866a341896aca528615d2d}{depth()}} -\/ 1,\mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a03cdb8e4b45371862c65c3b5be7b697e}{spectrum()}} -\/ 1)}.
\item Due to the particular arrangement of the pixel buffers defined in C\+Img, you can omit one coordinate if the corresponding dimension is equal to {\ttfamily 1}. For instance, pixels of a 2D image (\mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_aa708d2050f866a341896aca528615d2d}{depth()}} equal to {\ttfamily 1}) can be accessed by {\ttfamily img(x,y,c)} instead of {\ttfamily img(x,y,0,c)}. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}
\begin{DoxyWarning}{Warning}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item There is {\itshape no} boundary checking done in this operator, to make it as fast as possible. You {\itshape must} take care of out-\/of-\/bounds access by yourself, if necessary. For debugging purposes, you may want to define macro {\ttfamily \textquotesingle{}cimg\+\_\+verbosity\textquotesingle{}$>$=3} to enable additional boundary checking operations in this operator. In that case, warning messages will be printed on the error output when accessing out-\/of-\/bounds pixels. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyWarning}
\begin{DoxyParagraph}{Example}

\begin{DoxyCode}{0}
\DoxyCodeLine{CImg<float> \mbox{\hyperlink{namespacecimg__library__suffixed_a4b2be1eebcd69c87bde0b5757cad1938}{img}}(100,100,1,3,0); \textcolor{comment}{// Construct a 100x100x1x3 (color) image with pixels set to '0'}}
\DoxyCodeLine{\textcolor{keyword}{const} \textcolor{keywordtype}{float}}
\DoxyCodeLine{   valR = \mbox{\hyperlink{namespacecimg__library__suffixed_a4b2be1eebcd69c87bde0b5757cad1938}{img}}(10,10,0,0), \textcolor{comment}{// Read red value at coordinates (10,10)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{   valG = \mbox{\hyperlink{namespacecimg__library__suffixed_a4b2be1eebcd69c87bde0b5757cad1938}{img}}(10,10,0,1), \textcolor{comment}{// Read green value at coordinates (10,10)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{   valB = \mbox{\hyperlink{namespacecimg__library__suffixed_a4b2be1eebcd69c87bde0b5757cad1938}{img}}(10,10,2),   \textcolor{comment}{// Read blue value at coordinates (10,10) (Z-\/coordinate can be omitted)}}

\DoxyCodeLine{\mbox{\hyperlink{namespacecimg__library__suffixed_a4b2be1eebcd69c87bde0b5757cad1938}{img}}(10,10,0) = \mbox{\hyperlink{namespacecimg__library__suffixed_a4b2be1eebcd69c87bde0b5757cad1938}{img}}(10,10,1) = \mbox{\hyperlink{namespacecimg__library__suffixed_a4b2be1eebcd69c87bde0b5757cad1938}{img}}(10,10,2) = avg; \textcolor{comment}{// Replace the color pixel (10,10) by the average grey value}}

In-\/place multiplication operator. 

Replace the image instance by the matrix multiplication between the image instance and the specified matrix {\ttfamily img}. 
\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em img} & Second operand of the matrix multiplication. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item It does {\itshape not} compute a pointwise multiplication between two images. For this purpose, use mul(const C\+Img$<$t$>$\&) instead.
\item The size of the image instance can be modified by this operator. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}
\begin{DoxyParagraph}{Example}

\begin{DoxyCode}{0}
\DoxyCodeLine{CImg<float> A(2,2,1,1, 1,2,3,4);   \textcolor{comment}{// Construct 2x2 matrix A = [1,2;3,4]}}
\DoxyCodeLine{\textcolor{keyword}{const} CImg<float> X(1,2,1,1, 1,2); \textcolor{comment}{// Construct 1x2 vector X = [1;2]}}
\DoxyCodeLine{A*=X;                              \textcolor{comment}{// Assign matrix multiplication A*X to 'A'}}
\DoxyCodeLine{\textcolor{comment}{// 'A' is now a 1x2 vector whose values are [5;11].}}
\end{DoxyCode}

In-\/place addition operator. 

Add values to image pixels, according to the values of the input image {\ttfamily img}. 
\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em img} & Input image to add. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item The size of the image instance is never modified.
\item It is not mandatory that input image {\ttfamily img} has the same size as the image instance. If less values are available in {\ttfamily img}, then the values are added periodically. For instance, adding one WxH scalar image (\mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a03cdb8e4b45371862c65c3b5be7b697e}{spectrum()}} equal to {\ttfamily 1}) to one WxH color image (\mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a03cdb8e4b45371862c65c3b5be7b697e}{spectrum()}} equal to {\ttfamily 3}) means each color channel will be incremented with the same values at the same locations. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}
\begin{DoxyParagraph}{Example}

\begin{DoxyCode}{0}
\DoxyCodeLine{CImg<float> img1(\textcolor{stringliteral}{"reference.jpg"}); \textcolor{comment}{// Load a RGB color image (img1.spectrum()==3)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{\textcolor{comment}{// Construct a scalar shading (img2.spectrum()==1).}}
\DoxyCodeLine{\textcolor{keyword}{const} CImg<float> img2(img1.width(),\mbox{\hyperlink{namespacecimg__library__suffixed_a4b2be1eebcd69c87bde0b5757cad1938}{img}}.height(),1,1,\textcolor{stringliteral}{"255*(x/w)\string^2"});}
\DoxyCodeLine{img1+=img2; \textcolor{comment}{// Add shading to each channel of 'img1'}}
\DoxyCodeLine{img1.cut(0,255); \textcolor{comment}{// Prevent [0,255] overflow}}
\DoxyCodeLine{(img2,img1).\mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a33594316b522954b5388986c9b15a52a}{display}}();}
\end{DoxyCode}
  
\end{DoxyParagraph}

In-\/place addition operator. 

Add specified {\ttfamily value} to all pixels of an image instance. 
\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em value} & Value to add. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item Resulting pixel values are casted to fit the pixel type {\ttfamily T}. For instance, adding {\ttfamily 0.\+2} to a {\ttfamily C\+Img$<$char$>$} is possible but does nothing indeed.
\item Overflow values are treated as with standard C++ numeric types. For instance, 
\begin{DoxyCode}{0}
\DoxyCodeLine{CImg<unsigned char> \mbox{\hyperlink{namespacecimg__library__suffixed_a4b2be1eebcd69c87bde0b5757cad1938}{img}}(100,100,1,1,255); \textcolor{comment}{// Construct a 100x100 image with pixel values '255'}}
\DoxyCodeLine{\mbox{\hyperlink{namespacecimg__library__suffixed_a4b2be1eebcd69c87bde0b5757cad1938}{img}}+=1;                                   \textcolor{comment}{// Add '1' to each pixels -\/> Overflow}}
\DoxyCodeLine{\textcolor{comment}{// here all pixels of image 'img' are equal to '0'.}}
\end{DoxyCode}

\item To prevent value overflow, you may want to consider pixel type {\ttfamily T} as {\ttfamily float} or {\ttfamily double}, and use \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a6febadf5e06f2560eb41a222c3b77833}{cut()}} after addition. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}
\begin{DoxyParagraph}{Example}

\begin{DoxyCode}{0}
\DoxyCodeLine{CImg<unsigned char> img1(\textcolor{stringliteral}{"reference.jpg"}); \textcolor{comment}{// Load a 8-\/bits RGB image (values in [0,255])}}
\DoxyCodeLine{CImg<float> img2(img1); \textcolor{comment}{// Construct a float-\/valued copy of 'img1'}}
\DoxyCodeLine{img2+=100; \textcolor{comment}{// Add '100' to pixel values -\/> goes out of [0,255] but no problems with floats}}

Construct an image list from two images. 

Return a new list of image ({\ttfamily \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImgList}{C\+Img\+List}}} instance) containing exactly two elements\+:
\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item A copy of the image instance, at position \mbox{[}{\ttfamily 0}\mbox{]}.
\item A copy of the specified image {\ttfamily img}, at position \mbox{[}{\ttfamily 1}\mbox{]}.
\end{DoxyItemize}


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em img} & Input image that will be the second image of the resulting list. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item The family of \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a6ebae31a5555c02db8cd65f43b0e1aa2}{operator,()}} is convenient to easily create list of images, but it is also {\itshape quite} {\itshape slow} in practice (see warning below).
\item Constructed lists contain no shared images. If image instance or input image {\ttfamily img} are shared, they are inserted as new non-\/shared copies in the resulting list.
\item The pixel type of the returned list may be a superset of the initial pixel type {\ttfamily T}, if necessary. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}
\begin{DoxyWarning}{Warning}

\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item Pipelining \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a6ebae31a5555c02db8cd65f43b0e1aa2}{operator,()}} {\ttfamily N} times will perform {\ttfamily N} copies of the entire content of a (growing) image list. This may become very expensive in terms of speed and used memory. You should avoid using this technique to build a new \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImgList}{C\+Img\+List}} instance from several images, if you are seeking for performance. Fast insertions of images in an image list are possible with \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImgList_a84deef3a7cce5b08836947886ccdffac}{C\+Img\+List$<$\+T$>$\+::insert(const C\+Img$<$t$>$\&,unsigned int,bool)}} or \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_ab699a53c5b2d044549d1b61c6bcb3c9b}{move\+\_\+to(\+C\+Img\+List$<$t$>$\&,unsigned int)}}. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyWarning}

\item String parameter {\ttfamily expression} may describe different things\+:
\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item If {\ttfamily expression} is a list of values (as in {\ttfamily \char`\"{}1,2,3,8,3,2\char`\"{}}), or a formula (as in {\ttfamily \char`\"{}(x$\ast$y)\%255\char`\"{}}), the pixel values are set from specified {\ttfamily expression} and the image size is not modified.
\item If {\ttfamily expression} is a filename (as in {\ttfamily \char`\"{}reference.\+jpg\char`\"{}}), the corresponding image file is loaded and replace the image instance. The image size is modified if necessary. 
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyItemize}
\end{DoxyNote}
\begin{DoxyParagraph}{Example}

\begin{DoxyCode}{0}
\DoxyCodeLine{CImg<float> img1(100,100), img2(img1), img3(img1); \textcolor{comment}{// Declare 3 scalar images 100x100 with uninitialized values}}
\DoxyCodeLine{img1 = \textcolor{stringliteral}{"0,50,100,150,200,250,200,150,100,50"}; \textcolor{comment}{// Set pixel values of 'img1' from a value sequence}}
\DoxyCodeLine{img2 = \textcolor{stringliteral}{"10*((x*y)\%25)"};                       \textcolor{comment}{// Set pixel values of 'img2' from a formula}}
\DoxyCodeLine{img3 = \textcolor{stringliteral}{"reference.jpg"};                       \textcolor{comment}{// Set pixel values of 'img3' from a file (image size is modified)}}
\DoxyCodeLine{(img1,img2,img3).\mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a33594316b522954b5388986c9b15a52a}{display}}();}
\end{DoxyCode}

Return the number of image channels, i.\+e. the image dimension along the C-\/axis. \begin{DoxyNote}{Note}

\begin{DoxyItemize}

\item \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a03cdb8e4b45371862c65c3b5be7b697e}{spectrum()}} is typically equal to {\ttfamily 1} when considering scalar-\/valued images, to {\ttfamily 3} for R\+G\+B-\/coded color images, and to {\ttfamily 4} for R\+G\+B\+A-\/coded color images (with alpha-\/channel). The number of channels of an image instance is not limited. The meaning of the pixel values is not linked up to the number of channels (e.\+g. a 4-\/channel image may indifferently stands for a R\+G\+BA or C\+M\+YK color image).
\item \mbox{\hyperlink{structcimg__library__suffixed_1_1CImg_a03cdb8e4b45371862c65c3b5be7b697e}{spectrum()}} returns an {\ttfamily int}, although the image spectrum is internally stored as an {\ttfamily unsigned} {\ttfamily int}. Using an {\ttfamily int} is safer and prevents arithmetic traps possibly encountered when doing calculations involving {\ttfamily unsigned} {\ttfamily int} variables. Access to the initial {\ttfamily unsigned} {\ttfamily int} variable is possible (though not recommended) by {\ttfamily ($\ast$this).\+\_\+spectrum}. 
\end{DoxyItemize}

Compute the S\+VD of the instance image, viewed as a general matrix. 

Compute the S\+VD decomposition {\ttfamily $\ast$this=U$\ast$\+S$\ast$V\textquotesingle{}} where {\ttfamily U} and {\ttfamily V} are orthogonal matrices and {\ttfamily S} is a diagonal matrix. {\ttfamily V\textquotesingle{}} denotes the matrix transpose of {\ttfamily V}.

\mbox{\texttt{ out}}  & {\em U} & First matrix of the S\+VD product. \\
\hline

\hline
\mbox{\texttt{ out}}  & {\em V} & Third matrix of the S\+VD product. \\
\hline
 & {\em sorting} & Tells if the diagonal coefficients are sorted (in decreasing order). \\
\hline
 & {\em max\+\_\+iteration} & Maximum number of iterations considered for the algorithm convergence. \\
\hline
 & {\em lambda} & Epsilon used for the algorithm convergence. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}

\DoxyCodeLine{A.SVD(U,S,V)}
\end{DoxyCode}
 
\end{DoxyNote}

\begin{DoxyItemize}

Return the variance of the pixel values. 


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em variance\+\_\+method} & Method used to estimate the variance. Can be\+:
\begin{DoxyItemize}
\item {\ttfamily 0}\+: Second moment, computed as $1/N \sum\limits_{k=1}^{N} (x_k - \bar x)^2 = 1/N \left( \sum\limits_{k=1}^N x_k^2 - \left( \sum\limits_{k=1}^N x_k \right)^2 / N \right)$ with $ \bar x = 1/N \sum\limits_{k=1}^N x_k $.
\item {\ttfamily 1}\+: Best unbiased estimator, computed as $\frac{1}{N - 1} \sum\limits_{k=1}^{N} (x_k - \bar x)^2 $.
\item {\ttfamily 2}\+: Least median of squares.
\item {\ttfamily 3}\+: Least trimmed of squares. 
\end{DoxyItemize}\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
